security: This document reveals a Senate Select Committee hearing regarding the CIA's involvement in a plot to assassinate Patrice Lumumba. It includes the testimony of Bronson Tweedy, who discusses the authority he believed he had from higher-ups to explore such actions. Quoting directly, 'I was quite clear in my mind that the policy levels of Washington were agreed that Lumumba must go,' and 'It is perfectly obvious that the Agency felt that it had the support of the Executive in efforts to eliminate Lumumba.' This information could damage the CIA's reputation and reveal past operations.
summary: A transcript of a Senate Select Committee hearing featuring Bronson Tweedy's testimony about the CIA's involvement in exploring the assassination of Patrice Lumumba.
summary_one_paragraph: This document is a transcript from a Senate Select Committee hearing held on October 9, 1975, featuring the testimony of Bronson Tweedy regarding the CIA's potential involvement in the assassination of Patrice Lumumba. Tweedy discusses his conversations with Richard Bissell and the directives he received, including a cable from Allen Dulles, which indicated that the elimination of Lumumba was a policy-level decision. The hearing explores the extent of the CIA's actions, including dispatching Sidney Gottlieb to the Congo with lethal materials, and the degree to which these actions were authorized by the highest levels of the U.S. government.
title: Hearing before Senate Select Committee to Study Governmental Operations With Respect to Intelligence Activities
